title: Joab's Wise Counsel
shortSummary: In 2 Samuel 14, Joab devises a clever plan to bring Absalom back from exile by sending a wise woman to appeal to King David's sense of justice and mercy. The chapter highlights themes of reconciliation, justice, and the complexities of family relationships within the context of God's providence over the king's decisions.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Joab
keyCharacters.description: David’s military commander who orchestrates the plan to reconcile Absalom with King David.

keyCharacters.name: King David
keyCharacters.description: The king of Israel who is moved by the wise woman’s plea and ultimately allows Absalom to return.

keyCharacters.name: Absalom
keyCharacters.description: David’s son who has been in exile after killing his brother, and who is brought back to Jerusalem but remains estranged from the king.

keyCharacters.name: Wise Woman of Tekoah
keyCharacters.description: A shrewd and articulate woman sent by Joab to present a parable to King David to soften his heart toward Absalom.

definitions.definition: Clothing worn to signify grief, often plain and dark, used in biblical times to show sorrow for the dead.
Relatives who had the duty to avenge the death of a family member, often by killing the offender, according to the law of the Old Testament.
To apply oil ceremonially, often symbolizing consecration or honor; the wise woman was instructed not to anoint herself to show prolonged mourning.

outline.heading: Joab’s Perception and the Wise Woman’s Arrival
outline.description: Joab notices King David’s longing for Absalom’s return and sends a wise woman from Tekoah to present a fabricated case to the king, setting the stage for a plea for mercy and justice.

outline.heading: The Woman’s Parable and David’s Response
outline.description: The woman tells a story about two brothers and a family dispute, prompting David to reflect on justice and mercy, which leads him to reconsider his stance on Absalom’s exile.

outline.heading: Revelation of Joab’s Involvement and David’s Decision
outline.description: The woman reveals Joab’s role in the plan, and David commands Joab to bring Absalom back, though Absalom is not allowed to see the king’s face immediately.

outline.heading: Absalom’s Life in Jerusalem and His Strained Relationship with Joab
outline.description: Absalom’s physical beauty and family life are described, but his estrangement from David continues; his frustration with Joab leads to a dramatic incident, culminating in Joab facilitating Absalom’s reconciliation with the king.

application: Seek God’s wisdom in difficult family and leadership situations, trusting His providence to guide reconciliation.
Use wise and gentle speech to appeal to others’ hearts, as the wise woman did, demonstrating the power of tactful communication.
Be willing to forgive and restore relationships, reflecting God’s mercy as David ultimately shows to Absalom.
Recognize the importance of intercession and advocacy in helping others find restoration and peace.

keyVerses.text: For we must needs die, and are as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again; neither doth God respect any person: yet doth he devise means, that his banished be not expelled from him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's impartiality and His providential care even for those who are banished, emphasizing hope for restoration.

keyVerses.text: And the king said unto Joab, Behold now, I have done this thing: go therefore, bring the young man Absalom again.
keyVerses.significance: David’s decision to bring Absalom back marks a pivotal moment of mercy and reconciliation in the narrative.

keyVerses.text: So Joab came to the king, and told him: and when he had called for Absalom, he came to the king, and bowed himself on his face to the ground before the king: and the king kissed Absalom.
keyVerses.significance: The king’s kiss symbolizes full restoration and acceptance, showing the power of forgiveness and reconciliation.
